{{Culture of Japan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}}
[[Marriage]] in [[Japan]] is a legal and social institution at the center of the [[Ie (Japanese family system)|household]]. Couples are legally married once they have made the change in status on their [[Koseki|family registration sheets]], without the need for a ceremony. Most weddings are held either according to [[Shinto]] traditions or in chapels according to [[Christian views on marriage|Christian marriage traditions]].
Traditionally, marriages were categorized into two types according to the method of finding a partner—''[[Miai|omiai]]'', meaning arranged or resulting from an arranged introduction, and ''ren'ai'', in which the husband and wife met and decided to marry on their own—although the distinction has grown less meaningful over postwar decades as [[Westernization|Western]] ideas of [[Romance (love)|love]] alter Japanese perceptions of marriage.<ref>Edwards, ''Modern Japan Through its Weddings''.</ref>
== History == The institution of marriage in Japan has changed radically over the last millennium. Indigenous practices adapted first to [[China|Chinese]] [[Confucianism]] during the [[History of Japan#Medieval Japan|medieval era]], and then to [[Westernization|Western]] concepts of [[individualism]], [[gender equality]], [[Romance (love)|romantic love]], and the [[nuclear family]] during the [[History of Japan#Modern Japan|modern era]]. Customs once exclusive to a small [[Aristocracy (class)|aristocracy]] gained mass popularity as the [[Japanese people|population]] became increasingly [[urbanization|urbanized]].
=== Heian period (794–1185) === [[File:Genji emaki 01003 009.jpg|thumb|[[Hikaru Genji|Genji's]] son {{Nihongo|Yūgiri|夕霧||"Evening Mist"}} reads a letter. ''[[Genji Monogatari|Genji Monogatari Emaki]]'', 12th century handscroll, Gotoh Museum.]]
The [[Heian period]] of Japanese history marked the culmination of its classical era, when the vast [[Imperial Court in Kyoto|imperial court]] established itself and its culture in [[Heian-kyō]] (modern [[Kyoto]]). Heian society was organized by an [[Japanese castes under the ritsuryō|elaborate system of rank]], and the purpose of marriage was to produce children who would inherit the highest possible rank from the best-placed [[Lineage (anthropology)|lineage]]. It was neither ceremonial nor necessarily permanent.<ref name=JREF>{{cite web|title=Society: Marriage in Japan|url=http://www.jref.com/articles/marriage-in-japan.223/|website=Japan Reference|accessdate=21 January 2016|date=4 March 2013}}</ref>
Aristocrats exchanged letters and [[Japanese poetry|poetry]] for a period of months or years before arranging to meet after dark. If a man saw the same woman for a period of three nights, they were considered married, and the wife's parents held a banquet for the couple. Most members of the lower-class engaged in a permanent marriage with one partner, and husbands arranged to bring their wives into their own household, in order to ensure the [[Legitimacy (family law)|legitimacy]] of their offspring.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kurihara|first1=Hiromu|title=Heian-jidai no Rikon no Kenkyu|date=1999|publisher=Kobundo|location=Tokyo}}</ref>
High-ranked noblemen sometimes kept multiple wives or [[Concubinage|concubines]]. Aristocratic wives could remain in their fathers' house, and the husband would recognize [[Paternity (law)|paternity]] with the formal presentation of a gift.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kurihara|first1=Hiromu|title=Heian-jidai no Rikon no Kenkyu|date=1999|publisher=Kobundo|location=Tokyo}}</ref> The forms of Heian [[courtship]], as well as the pitfalls of amorous intrigue, are well represented in the [[Heian literature|literature]] of the period, especially ''[[The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter]]'', ''[[Sarashina Nikki|The Sarashina Diary]]'', ''[[The Pillow Book]]'', and ''[[The Tale of Genji]]''.
=== Edo period (1600–1868) === [[File:Japanese wedding. Before 1902.jpg|thumb|"Wedding." From the book ''Japan and Japanese'' (1902), p. 62.]] [[File:Japanese at home. Before 1902.jpg|thumb|"Japanese at home." From the book ''Japan and Japanese'' (1902), p. 71.]] In pre-modern Japan, marriage was inextricable from the {{Nihongo|''[[Ie (Japanese family system)|ie]]''|家||"family" or "household"}}, the basic unit of society with a collective continuity independent of any individual life. Members of the household were expected to subordinate all their own interests to that of the ''ie'', with respect for an ideal of [[filial piety]] and [[Social stratification|social hierarchy]] that borrowed much from [[Confucian view of marriage|Confucianism]].<ref name="Hendry, pp. 15-6">Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 15-6.</ref> The choice to [[Bachelor|remain single]] was the greatest crime a man could commit, according to [[Hozumi Nobushige|Baron Hozumi]].<ref>Hozumi, Nobushige. ''Ancestor-Worship and Japanese Law.'' University Press of the Pacific, 2003. {{ISBN|1-4102-0838-9}}.</ref>
Marriages were duly arranged by the head of the household, who represented it publicly and was legally responsible for its members, and any preference by either principal in a marital arrangement was considered improper. Property was regarded to belong to the ''ie'' rather than to individuals, and inheritance was strictly [[Primogeniture#Agnatic primogeniture|agnatic primogeniture]]. A woman (女) married the household (家) of her husband, hence the [[Kanji|logograms]] for {{Nihongo|''yome''|嫁||"wife"}} and {{Nihongo|''yomeiri''|嫁入り||"marriage," lit. "wife entering"}}.<ref name="Hendry, pp. 15-6"/>
In the absence of sons, some households would adopt a {{Nihongo|[[Mukoyōshi|male heir]]|養子||or yōshi}} to maintain the dynasty, a practice which continues in corporate Japan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kapur|first1=Roshni|title=Welcome to the family: Adult adoptions in corporate Japan|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/119305-japan-adult-male-adoption|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=Rappler|date=17 January 2016}}</ref> Nearly all adoptions are of adult men.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hartson|first1=William|title=Top 10 facts about Japan|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/top10facts/642958/top-facts-Japan-National-Foundation-Day|accessdate=17 February 2016|work=Express|date=11 February 2016}}</ref> Marriage was restricted to households of equal social standing (分限), which made selection a crucial, painstaking process. Although Confucian ethics encouraged people to marry outside their own group, limiting the search to a local community remained the easiest way to ensure an honorable match. Approximately one-in-five marriages in pre-modern Japan occurred between households that were already related.<ref name=JREF/>
Outcast communities such as the [[Burakumin]] could not marry outside of their [[caste]], and marriage discrimination continued even after an 1871 edict abolished the caste system, well into the twentieth century. Marriage [[International marriage (Japan)|between a Japanese and non-Japanese person]] was not officially permitted until 14 March 1873, a date now commemorated as [[White Day]]. Marriage with a foreigner required the Japanese national to surrender his or her social standing.
[[File:Kanbun Master - 'Lovers Surprised', late 1660s, Honolulu Academy of Arts.jpg|thumb|''Caught in the Act'', a hanging scroll by the [[Kanbun Master]], late 1660s, [[Honolulu Museum of Art]].]] The purposes of marriage in the [[History of Japan#Medieval Japan|medieval]] and [[Edo period]]s was to form alliances between families, to relieve the family of its female dependents, to perpetuate the family line, and, especially for the lower classes, to add new members to the family's workforce. The seventeenth-century treatise ''Onna Daigaku'' ("Greater Learning for Women") instructed wives honor their parents-in-law before their own parents, and to be "courteous, humble, and conciliatory" towards their husbands.<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 18, 22.</ref>
Husbands were also encouraged to place the needs of their parents and children before those of their wives. One British observer remarked, "If you love your wife you spoil your mother's servant."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sladen|first1=Douglas|last2=Lorimer|first2=Norma|title=More Queer Things About Japan|date=1904|publisher=Anthony Treherne|location=London|page=384}}</ref> The tension between a [[housewife]] and her [[Parent-in-law#Mothers-in-law|mother-in-law]] has been a keynote of [[Japanese television drama|Japanese drama]] ever since.
{{Nihongo|[[Romance (love)|Romantic love]]|愛情||''aijō''}} played little part in medieval marriages, as emotional attachment was considered inconsistent with filial piety. A proverb said, "Those who come together in passion stay together in tears."<ref>Tamura, ''The Japanese Bride'', p. 3.</ref> For men, sexual gratification was seen as separate from conjugal relations with one's wife, where the purpose was [[Reproduction|procreation]]. The genre called {{Nihongo|''[[Ukiyo-e]]''|浮世絵||lit. "floating world pictures"}} celebrated the luxury and hedonism of the era, typically with depictions of beautiful [[oiran|courtesans]] and [[geisha]] of the [[Yūkaku|pleasure districts]]. [[Concubinage]] and [[Prostitution in Japan|prostitution]] were common, public, relatively respectable, until the social upheaval of the [[Meiji Restoration]] put an end to [[Feudalism|feudal]] [[Edo society|society]] in Japan.<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 19-21. Fukutake, ''Japanese Rural Society'', p. 44.</ref>
=== Meiji Restoration and modernization (1868–1912) === [[File:Showa-family1941 12 7.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|The [[Hirohito|Shōwa Emperor]] (Hirohito) with his wife [[Empress Kōjun]] and their children in 1941.]] During the [[Meiji period]], upper class and [[samurai]] customs of [[arranged marriage]] steadily replaced the unions of choice and mutual attraction that rural commoners had once enjoyed. Rapid [[urbanization]] and [[Industrialisation|industrialization]] brought more of the population into the cities, ending the isolation of rural life. [[State school|Public education]] became almost universal between 1872 and the early 1900s, and schools stressed the traditional concept of filial piety, first toward the [[Empire of Japan|nation]], second toward the household, and last of all toward a person's own private interests. Marriage under the Meiji Civil Code required the permission of the head of a household (Article 750) and of the parents for men under 30 and women under 25 (Article 772).<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 14, 16-7, 22-3.</ref>
In arranged marriages, most couples met beforehand at a formal introduction called an {{Nihongo|''[[Miai|omiai]]''|お見合い||lit. "looking at one another"}}, although some would meet for the first time at the wedding ceremony. A visitor to Japan described the ''omiai'' as "a meeting at which the lovers (if persons unknown to each other may be so styled) are allowed to see, sometimes even to speak to each other, and thus estimate each others' merits."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chamberlain|first1=Basil Hall|title=Things Japanese|date=1902|publisher=John Murray|location=London|page=309|edition=4th}}</ref> However, their objections carried little weight. The meeting was originally a samurai custom which became widespread during the early twentieth century, when commoners began to arrange marriages for their children through a {{Nihongo|go-between|仲人|, nakōdo}} or [[Matchmaking|matchmaker]]. The word ''omiai'' is still used to distinguish arranged marriages, even when no formal meeting takes place, from {{Nihongo|''ren'ai''|恋愛||a "love match"}}.<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 18, 22-3.</ref>
[[Courtship]] remained rare in Japan at this period. Boys and girls were separated in [[Single-sex education|schools]], in cinemas, and at social gatherings. Colleagues who began a romantic relationship could be dismissed, and during the [[Pacific War|Second World War]] traveling couples could be arrested. Parents sometimes staged an arranged marriage to legitimize a "love match," but many others resulted in separation and sometimes [[Shinjū|suicide]].<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 24-5.</ref> Love was thought to be inessential to marriage. A proposal by Baron Hozumi, who had studied abroad, that the absence of love be made a grounds for divorce failed to pass during debates on the Meiji Civil Code of 1898.<ref>{{cite book|last1=West|first1=Mark D.|title=Lovesick Japan: Sex, Marriage, Romance, Law|date=2011|publisher=Cornell University Press|page=183}}</ref> One writer observed in 1930, "According to the traditional moral ideas, it is deemed a sign of mental and moral weakness to '[[Falling in love|fall in love]].'"<ref>Kawashima, ''Kekkon'', pp. 143f.</ref>
Marriage, like other social institutions of this period, emphasized the subordinate inferiority of women to men. Women learned that as a daughter they ought to obey their father, as a wife their husband, as a widow their sons. [[Chastity]] in marriage was expected for women, and a law not repealed until 1908 allowed a husband to kill his wife and her lover if he found them in an [[Adultery|adulterous act]]. The prostitution of women survived the periodic intrusion of [[Religion and sexuality#Christianity|puritanical ideals]] on Japan's less restrictive [[Sexuality in Japan|sexuality]].<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', p. 21</ref>
[[Family law in Japan#Divorce|Divorce laws]] become more equal over time. During the Edo period, a husband could [[divorce]] his wife by writing a letter of his intent to do so, but a wife's only recourse was to flee to a [[convent]]. The laws of the early Meiji period established several grounds on which a man could divorce: [[Sterility (physiology)|sterility]], adultery, disobedience to parents-in-law, loquacity, [[larceny]], jealousy, and disease. A wife, accompanied by a close male relative, could appeal for divorce if she had been deserted or imprisoned by her husband, or if he was profligate or [[Mental disorder|mentally ill]]. The 1898 Civil Code established the principle of mutual consent, although the consent of women was still likely to be forced until the early twentieth century, as women gradually gained access to education and financial independence.<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 21-2</ref> The fight for divorce rights marked the beginning of [[Feminism in Japan|Japanese feminism]].
=== Post-war period (1945–present) === Signed after the [[Surrender of Japan|surrender]] and [[occupation of Japan]] by [[Allies of World War II|Allied forces]], Article 24 of the [[Constitution of Japan|Constitution of 1947]] reestablished marriage on grounds of [[Gender equality|equality]] and choice: "Marriage shall be based only on the mutual consent of both sexes and it shall be maintained through mutual cooperation with the equal rights of husband and wife as a base. With regard to choice of spouse, property rights, inheritance, choice of domicile, divorce and other matters pertaining to marriage and the family, all laws shall be enacted from the standpoint of individual dignity and the essential equality of the sexes."
[[File:Japanese family meal in 1950s.jpg|thumb|A family meal in the 1950s.]] The Constitution abolished the foundations of the ''ie'' system and the [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] authority at its heart. Each [[nuclear family]] retained, and still retains, a separate [[Koseki|family registration sheet]], initiated on marriage under the [[surname]] of the husband or wife, but the head of each household no longer had any special legal prerogatives over his or her dependents. All legitimate children, male or female, gained an equal right to [[inheritance]], putting an end to primogeniture succession and the obsession with lineage. Women received the [[Women's suffrage in Japan|right to vote]] and the right to request a divorce on the basis of infidelity. The Meiji emphasis on Confucian values and [[Kokutai|national mythology]] disappeared from education.<ref>Hendry, ''Marriage in Changing Japan'', pp. 26-8</ref> The conventional model of the ''ie'' was replaced with a new convention, the {{Nihongo|''kazoku''|家族||family}} and the {{Nihongo|''kakukazoku''|核家族||nuclear family}}, as the fundamental unit of society.<ref name=Kelly>Kelly, William. "Finding a Place in Metropolitan Japan: Transpositions of Everyday Life." Ed. Andrew Gordon. ''Postwar Japan as History''. University of California Press, 1993. P. 208-10.</ref>
New demographic trends emerged, including a later [[Age at first marriage|age of marriage]] and a smaller difference in age between groom and bride,<ref>{{cite web|author1=E-Stat|title=Trends in mean age of bride and groom at marriage and difference in mean age between bride and groom|url=http://www.e-stat.go.jp/SG1/estat/GL38020103.do?_toGL38020103_&listID=000001137969&requestSender=estat|website=Vital Statistics of Japan|accessdate=21 January 2016|location=Table 9-12|date=3 September 2015}}</ref> the birth of two children in quick succession, few children born out of wedlock, and a low [[divorce rate]].<ref>Coleman, Samuel. "The Tempo of Family Formation." Ed. David W. Plath. ''Work and Lifecourse in Japan''. Albany: SUNY Press, 1983. P. 183-214.</ref> [[Shūshin koyō|Lifetime employment]] became the norm for Japanese men, especially during the [[Japanese post-war economic miracle|post-war economic boom]] of the 1950s, 60s, and 70s. A [[middle class]] ideology established a [[Gender role|gendered family pattern]] with separate social spheres: a [[Salaryman|salaried husband]] to provide the family income, a [[housewife]] to manage the home and nurture the children, and a commitment by the children to education.<ref name=Cengage>Schirokauer, Conrad, Miranda Brown, David Lurie, and Suzanne Gay. ''A Brief History of Chinese and Japanese Civilizations''. 4th ed. Boston: Cengage Learning, 2013. P. 609-10.</ref> Better health and nutrition meant a rapid extension of [[life expectancy]], and government policies have encouraged people to form {{Nihongo|''sansedai kazoku''|三世代家族||"three-generation families"}} to manage a [[Aging of Japan|rapidly aging society]].<ref name=Kelly/>
''Omiai'' marriages, arranged by the parents or a matchmaker, remained the norm immediately after the war, although the decades which followed saw a steady rise in the number of ''ren'ai'' "love matches." The distinction between the two has blurred: parents almost always consulted young people before "arranging" a marriage, and many young people asked an employer or teacher to serve as matchmaker for their "love match."<ref name=Cengage/> Today only one in 20 married couples describe their formation as arranged, and a courtship of several years has become the norm even for relationships that begin with an ''omiai''. Three in five couples meet in the workplace or through friends or siblings.<ref>IPSS, "Marriage Process and Fertility of Japanese Married Couples" (2011), table 1.1, 1.3.</ref>
[[Online dating service]]s in Japan gained a reputation as platforms for soliciting sex, often from [[Minor (law)|underage girls]], for [[sexual harassment]] and [[sexual assault|assault]], and for using decoy accounts (called ''otori'' or ''sakura'' in Japanese) to string along users in order to extend their [[subscription business model|subscriptions]]. Newer services like Pairs, with 8 million users, or Omiai have introduced ID checks, age limits, strict [[moderation]], and use of [[artificial intelligence]] to arrange matches for serious seekers. Profiles typically include age, location, height, career, and salary, but can also include interests, hobbies, and familial interests.<ref>{{cite news |last1=安楽 |first1=由紀子 |title=シリーズ・現代ニッポンの結婚事情：（2）婚活を効率化するマッチングサービス事情 |url=https://www.nippon.com/ja/features/c05602/ |accessdate=20 October 2018 |work=Nippon.com |date=18 October 2018}}</ref>
The term "marriage hunting" (''kekkon katsudo'', or ''konkatsu''), has become popular since 2007.<ref name=paradox>{{Cite book|title=The Paradox of Harmony|last=Hirata|first=Keiko|last2=Warschauer|first2=Mark|publisher=Yale University Press|year=2014|isbn=9780300186079|location=New Haven|pages=|via=}}</ref>{{rp|82}} It reflects a professional class of matchmaking services which arrange meetings between potential partners, typically through social events, and often includes the exchange of resumes.<ref name="paradox" />{{rp|83}}
== Demographic == {{main article|Demography of Japan}} According to the 2010 census, 58.9% of Japan's adult population is married, 13.9% of women and 3.1% of men are widowed, and 5.9% of women and 3.8% of men are divorced.<ref>{{cite book|title=Populations and Households of Japan 2010|location=Table 3.1|page=33|url=http://www.stat.go.jp/english/data/kokusei/2010/poj/pdf/2010ch03.pdf|accessdate=18 January 2016|format=PDF|chapter=Chapter 3: Marital Status}}</ref> The annual number of marriages has dropped since the early 1970s, while divorces have shown a general upward trend.<ref name=Handbook>{{cite web|author1=Statistics Bureau, Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, Japan|title=Statistical Handbook of Japan 2014|url=http://www.stat.go.jp/english/data/handbook/c0117.htm|accessdate=18 January 2016|location=Chapter 5}}</ref>
=== Marriage and fertility === [[File:Non marital by countries.gif|thumb|450px|The percentage of births to unmarried women in selected countries, 1980 and 2007.<ref name="non_mar1">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/databriefs/db18.htm|title=Changing Patterns of Nonmarital Childbearing in the United States |work=CDC/National Center for Health Statistics|date=May 13, 2009|accessdate=September 24, 2011}}</ref> As can be seen in the figure, Japan has not followed the trend of other Western countries of children born outside of marriage to the same degree.]]
The decline of marriage in Japan, as fewer people marry and do so later in life, is a widely cited explanation for the [[Aging of Japan|plummeting birth rate]].<ref name=Handbook/><ref name=Yamada>{{cite news|last1=Yamada|first1=Masahiro|title=Japan’s Deepening Social Divides: Last Days for the "Parasite Singles"|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a01002/|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=3 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sudo|first1=Yoko|title=Japan's Low Marriage Rate Concerns Minister|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-low-marriage-rate-concerns-minister-1405669862|accessdate=12 April 2016|work=Wall Street Journal|date=18 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=Economist>{{cite news|title=Why the Japanese are having so few babies|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2014/07/economist-explains-16|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Economist|date=23 July 2014}}</ref> Although the [[total fertility rate]] has dropped since the 1970s (to 1.43 in 2013<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan Statistical Yearbook, Chapter 2: Population and Households|url=http://www.stat.go.jp/english/data/nenkan/1431-02.htm|author=Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communication, Statistics Bureau|accessdate=13 January 2016|location=Table 2-25}}</ref>), birth statistics for married women have remained fairly constant (at around 2.1) and most married couples have two or more children. Economic factors, such as the [[cost of raising a child]], [[Work–life balance|work-family conflicts]], and [[Housing in Japan|insufficient housing]], are the most common reasons for young mothers (under 34) to have fewer children than desired.<ref>IPSS, "Marriage Process and Fertility of Japanese Married Couples" (2011), pp. 9-14.</ref>
The number of single-child or childless couples has increased since 2002 (to 23.3 percent in 2010) even as the desire for larger families remains the same.<ref>IPSS, "Marriage Process and Fertility of Japanese Married Couples" (2011), pp. 9-14.</ref> Only 2% of births occur [[Legitimacy (family law)#Extramarital births|outside of marriage]],<ref>{{cite web|title=人口動態調査（平成26年）|url=http://www.e-stat.go.jp/SG1/estat/GL02020101.do?method=csvDownload&fileId=000007464055&releaseCount=1|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref> compared to 30-60% of births in Europe and North America.<ref name=Economist/> This is due to social taboos, [[Family law in Japan#Children|legal pressure]], and financial hurdles.<ref name=Economist/>
Half of Japan's [[single parent|single mothers]] live below the poverty line, among the highest for [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD countries]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=WuDunn|first1=Sheryl|title=Stigma Curtails Single Motherhood in Japan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/13/world/stigma-curtails-single-motherhood-in-japan.html|accessdate=13 January 2016|work=The New York Times|date=13 March 1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Imamura|first1=Yuri|last2=Imamura|first2=Hisanori|last3=Okabayashi|first3=Sawa|last4=Yamada|first4=Kana|title=Half of single-mother households in Japan below poverty line, among worst in OECD rankings|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201409090005|accessdate=13 January 2016|work=The Asahi Shimbun|date=9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Akaishi|first1=Chieko|title=The Plight of Japan's Single Mothers|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a04603/|accessdate=13 January 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=24 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Brasor|first1=Philip|last2=Tsubuku|first2=Masako|title=No relief in sight for Japan's poor single-parent families|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/11/07/business/no-relief-sight-japans-poor-single-parent-families/|accessdate=13 January 2016|work=The Japan Times|date=7 November 2015}}</ref> In addition, an estimated 3.5 million Japanese children, one in six of those below the age of 18, are from households classed as experiencing "relative poverty" by the OECD.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title=Equality in Japan: is this vision of a fairer society too good to be true?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/apr/25/equality-japan-inequality-vision-fairer-society-too-good-to-be-true|website=The Guardian|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
=== Fewer marriages === Almost 90% of unmarried Japanese intend to marry,<ref>IPSS, "Attitudes toward Marriage and Family among Japanese Singles" (2011), p. 2.</ref> and yet the percentage of people who don't continues to rise. Between 1990 and 2010, the percentage of 50-year-old people who had never married roughly quadrupled for men to 20.1% and doubled for women to 10.6%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan Statistical Yearbook, Chapter 2: Population and Households|url=http://www.stat.go.jp/english/data/nenkan/1431-02.htm|author=Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communication, Statistics Bureau|accessdate=13 January 2016|location=Table 2-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=White paper shows Japanese people delaying marriage, having children|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201306260063|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=Asahi Shimbun|date=26 June 2013}}</ref> The Welfare Ministry predicts these numbers to rise to 29% of men and 19.2% of women by 2035.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yoshida|first1=Reiji|title=Japan’s population dilemma, in a single-occupancy nutshell|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/12/31/national/social-issues/japans-population-dilemma-single-occupancy-nutshell/|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Japan Times|date=31 December 2015}}</ref> The government's population institute estimated in 2014 that women in their early 20s had a one-in-four chance of never marrying, and a two-in-five chance of remaining childless.<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|last1=Haworth|first1=Abigail|title=Why have young people in Japan stopped having sex?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/20/young-people-japan-stopped-having-sex|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Guardian|date=20 October 2013}}</ref>
Recent media coverage has sensationalized surveys from the [[Japan Family Planning Association]] and the Cabinet Office that show a declining interest in dating and [[Celibacy syndrome|sexual relationships]] among young people, especially among [[Herbivore men|men]].<ref name=Guardian/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Waldman|first1=Katy|title=Young People in Japan Have Given Up on Sex|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2013/10/22/celibacy_syndrome_in_japan_why_aren_t_young_people_interested_in_sex_or.html|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=Slate|date=22 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Osaki|first1=Tomohiro|title=For many young Japanese, marriage — and sex — are low priorities|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/01/05/national/social-issues/many-young-japanese-marriage-sex-low-priorities/|accessdate=19 February 2016|work=The Japan Times|date=5 January 2016}}</ref> However, changes in sexuality and fertility are more likely an outcome of the decline in family formation than its cause.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Matthews|first1=Dylan|title=Don’t worry. The Japanese are having plenty of sex|url=http://knowmore.washingtonpost.com/2013/10/23/yes-japanese-people-still-have-sex/|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=The Washington Post|issue=Know More blog|date=23 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Keating|first1=Joshua|title=No, Japanese People Haven't Given Up on Sex|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_world_/2013/10/23/are_japanese_people_really_having_less_sex_than_anyone_else.html|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=Slate|date=23 October 2013}}</ref> Since the usual purpose of dating in Japan is marriage, the reluctance to marry often translates to a reluctance to engage in more casual relationships.<ref name=Yamada/>
The majority of Japanese people remain committed to traditional ideas of family, with a husband who provides financial support, a [[Women in Japan|wife]] who [[Women's work|works in the home]], and two children.<ref name=Yamada/><ref>IPSS, "Marriage Process and Fertility of Japanese Married Couples" (2011), p. 9.</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=51% want wives to stay home: poll|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2012/12/17/national/51-want-wives-to-stay-home-poll/|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Japan Times|agency=Kyodo|date=17 December 2012}}</ref> [[Japanese work environment|Labor practices]], such as long [[Working time#Japan|working hours]], [[National Health Insurance (Japan)|health insurance]], and the [[National Pension|national pension system]], are premised on a traditional [[breadwinner model]]. As a result, Japan has largely maintained a [[Division of labour#Gendered division of labour|gender-based division of labor]] with one of the largest [[gender pay gap]]s in the [[Developed country|developed world]], even as other countries began moving towards more equal arrangements in the 1970s.<ref name="Yamada2">{{cite news|last1=Yamada|first1=Masahiro|title=The Future of the Japanese Family: Diversification or Virtualization?|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/column/g00347/|accessdate=27 March 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=17 March 2016}}</ref>
However, [[economic stagnation]], anemic [[wage]] growth,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Khan|first1=Mehreen|title=Can anything rescue Japan from the abyss?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/03/27/can-anything-stop-japan-from-falling-into-the-abyss/|accessdate=29 March 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=28 March 2016}}</ref> and [[Job security|job insecurity]] have made it more and more difficult for young Japanese couples to secure the income necessary to create a conventional family, despite their desire to do so.<ref name=Yamada2/> Japan was once well known for [[Shūshin koyō|lifetime employment]], but after the [[Japanese asset price bubble|asset price bubble burst]] and the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]] regular employment for unmarried men age 25-34 dropped from 78% in 1982 to 55% in 2010 as companies began employing more people on [[Temporary work|temporary]] or [[part-time contract]]s.<ref>IPSS, "Attitudes toward Marriage and Family among Japanese Singles" (2011), pp. 20-21.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Obe|first1=Mitsuru|title=Japan Has Plenty of Jobs, but Workers Still Struggle|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/japan-has-plenty-of-jobs-but-workers-still-struggle-1426197511|accessdate=12 April 2016|work=Wall Street Journal|date=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Murakami|first1=Naohisa|title=Regular Full-Time Positions Increasingly Elusive for Japanese Workers|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/features/h00133/|accessdate=7 March 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=29 February 2016}}</ref> These non-regular employees earn about 53% less than regular ones on a comparable monthly basis, according to the [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare|Labor Ministry]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nohara|first1=Yoshiaki|title=Japan Labor Shortage Prompts Shift to Hiring Permanent Workers|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-30/japan-s-labor-shortage-prompts-grudging-turn-to-permanent-jobs|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Bloomberg|date=1 May 2017}}</ref> and as primary earners are seven times more likely to fall below the poverty line.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title=Equality in Japan: is this vision of a fairer society too good to be true?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/apr/25/equality-japan-inequality-vision-fairer-society-too-good-to-be-true|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=The Guardian|date=25 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=OECD|title=OECD Economic Surveys: Japan 2017|date=2017|publisher=OECD Publishing|location=Paris|pages=47|url=http://www.keepeek.com/Digital-Asset-Management/oecd/economics/oecd-economic-surveys-japan-2017_eco_surveys-jpn-2017-en#page47|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> Men in this group are more than twice as reluctant to consider marriage,<ref>IPSS, "Attitudes toward Marriage and Family among Japanese Singles" (2011), p. 4.</ref> and in their 30s they are about 40% less likely to be married than those with regular employment.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hoenig|first1=Henry|last2=Obe|first2=Mitsuru|title=Why Japan’s Economy Is Laboring|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-japans-economy-is-laboring-1459929574|work=Wall Street Journal|date=8 April 2016}}</ref>
According to the sociologist [[Masahiro Yamada]], the failure of conventions to adapt to the economic and social realities of Japanese society has caused a "gap in family formation" between those who succeed in creating a conventional family and those who remain single and childless.<ref name=Yamada/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Leo|title=Japan: Deflated generation|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1b24264e-b9d8-11e5-bf7e-8a339b6f2164.html|accessdate=26 February 2016|work=Financial Times|date=13 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Later marriages === The average [[age at first marriage]] in Japan has climbed steadily from the middle of the 20th century to around 31 for men and 29 for women in 2013, among the highest in Asia.<ref name=Handbook/> Women postpone marriage for a variety of reasons, including high personal and financial expectations,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Efron|first1=Sonni|title=Me, Find a Husband? Later, Maybe|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jun/26/news/mn-14693|accessdate=18 January 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=26 June 2001}}</ref> increasing independence afforded by education and employment,<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian demography: The flight from marriage|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21526329|accessdate=18 January 2016|work=The Economist|date=20 August 2011}}</ref> and the difficulty of balancing work and family.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kawaguchi|first1=Akira|title=Japanese Women Face Tough Reality in Work and Marriage|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a04601/|accessdate=18 January 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=20 August 2015}}</ref> Masahiro Yamada coined the term {{nihongo|[[parasite single]]s|パラサイトシングル|parasaito shinguru}} for unmarried adults in their late 20s and 30s who live with their parents, though it usually refers to women.<ref name="Wiseman">{{cite news|last=Wiseman|first=Paul|title=No sex please we're Japanese|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2004-06-02-japan-women-usat_x.htm|accessdate=May 10, 2012|newspaper=USA Today|date=2 June 2004}}</ref> Men who do not aggressively pursue marriage are known as {{Nihongo|[[herbivore men]]|草食男子|''sōshoku danshi''}}.<ref>{{cite news|title= After the end of the world|work= [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=2011-03-23|url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/03/23/apop032311.DTL&ao=2|accessdate=2012-01-15|first=Jeff|last=Yang}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-16500768 | work=BBC News | title=Young Japanese 'decline to fall in love' | date=2012-01-11}}</ref>
=== International marriages === Of the 660,613 marriages registered in 2013, 21,488 (or about 1 in 30) were between a Japanese and a foreign national, according to the [[Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare]]. The number of international unions rose rapidly in the 1980s and 90s, peaked in 2006 at 44,701 (about 1 in 16), and has declined since then.<ref name=VitalStats>{{cite book|title=Vital Statistics in Japan: The Latest Trends|date=2013|publisher=Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare|page=32|url=http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/database/db-hw/dl/81-1a2en.pdf|accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref> Changes in the Immigration Control Act in 2005, which made it more difficult for [[Philippines|Philippine]] nationals to work in Japan, are one cause of the decline. Filipino women saw the largest drop, from 12,150 in 2006 to 3,118 or 20.1% of foreign brides in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Look at International Marriage in Japan|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/features/h00096/|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=19 February 2015}}</ref> Many Filipino women come to Japan as entertainers, and some have been victims of [[domestic violence]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cartelle|first1=Karryn|title=Foreign victims of domestic violence band together|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/lifestyle/view/foreign-victims-of-domestic-violence-band-together|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=Japan Today|date=8 June 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Center offers help to abused Filipinos|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/10/09/national/center-offers-help-to-abused-filipinos/|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=The Japan Times|agency=Kyodo|date=9 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sugiyama|first1=Haru|title=Kawasaki Youth’s Murder Exposes Japan’s Social and Policy Failings in Coping with Immigration|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/currents/d00176/|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=12 June 2015}}</ref>
The nationality of foreign spouses differs by gender, and Japanese women are more likely to marry partners from outside [[East Asia|East]] and [[Southeast Asia]] than Japanese men. Of the 15,442 non-Japanese brides in 2013, most came from [[China]] (40.4%), followed by the Philippines (20.1%), [[South Korea]] (17.7%), and [[Thailand]] (6.3%). The 6,046 grooms came from Korea (27.9%), the [[United States]] (19.1%), China (11.8%), and Brazil (4.7%).<ref name=VitalStats/> Many of the [[Chinese people in Japan|Chinese]] and [[Koreans in Japan|Korean (Zainichi)]] nationals included in these statistics have lived in Japan for generations without becoming naturalized citizens.
Of the 1 million children born in Japan in 2013, 2.2% had one or more non-Japanese parent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trends in live births by nationality of father and mother, 1995, 2000 and 2005-2013|url=http://www.e-stat.go.jp/SG1/estat/GL38020103.do?_toGL38020103_&listID=000001128913&requestSender=estat|website=e-Stat|accessdate=19 January 2016|location=Table 9|date=29 January 2015}}</ref> The rise in international households has sometimes led to [[International child abduction in Japan|conflicts over custody]]. Biracial Japanese children are often called {{nihongo|''[[hāfu]]''|ハーフ}}, although the term has its discontents.
=== Domestic violence === According to a summary of surveys by Japan's [[Gender Equality Bureau]] in 2006, 33.2% of wives and 17.4% of husbands have experienced either threats, physical violence, or [[Marital rape|rape]], more than 10% of women repeatedly. This violence almost always occurred after marriage. [[Dating abuse]] has also been reported by 13.5% of women and 5.2% of men.<ref>Gender Equality Bureau, Cabinet Office, Survey on Domestic Violence (Tokyo: Gender Equality Bureau, 2006) page 3, 9. (Published in Japanese only, English information available at: [http://www.gender.go.jp/evaw/book/images/pdf/stoptheviolence.pdf] or at: [http://www.whatjapanthinks.com/2006/04/23/domestic-violence-in-japan-part-1-of-3/])</ref>
== Marriage law == {{main article|Family law in Japan}} A marriage is legally recognized once a couple has successfully submitted the required documents to the [[city hall]] [[Civil registration|registrar]] to change their status in their {{nihongo|''koseki''|戸籍}} [[Family register|family registration sheet]]. No ceremony is required under [[Law of Japan|Japanese law]].<ref name=USEmbassy>[[Embassy of the United States in Tokyo|Embassy of the United States: Japan]], [http://tokyo.usembassy.gov/e/acs/tacs-7114a.html Marriage in Japan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527101216/http://tokyo.usembassy.gov/e/acs/tacs-7114a.html |date=27 May 2010 }}. Accessed 29 August 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.seiyaku.com/seiyaku/en/discussion/is-it-legal.html Western Style Weddings in Japan: Are they real weddings?] Seiyaku.com. Accessed 29 August 2008.</ref> The family registration sheet serves as [[birth certificate]], proof of citizenship, [[marriage license]], and [[death certificate]]. A register is kept for each nuclear family, under the name of the {{nihongo|head of the household|筆頭者||''hittousya''}}, with the spouse and unmarried children who are registered as dependents.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan's Family Registry System|url=http://japan.usembassy.gov/e/acs/tacs-family-registry.html|publisher=Embassy of the United States: Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
A couple who marries must file a {{nihongo|marriage registration form|婚姻届||''konin todoke''}} to create a {{nihongo|new registration sheet|新戸籍||''shinkoseki''}} under a common [[surname]]. Since 1947, couples have been permitted to choose either the surname of the husband or wife, consistent with a ban on separate surnames first imposed in 1898. Married couples are estimated to choose the man's surname 95% of the time, although some women continue to use their [[Maiden and married names|maiden name]] informally. The ban has survived several legal challenges on the basis of [[gender inequality]], most recently in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Soble|first1=Jonathan|title=Japan’s Top Court Upholds Law Requiring Spouses to Share Surname|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/17/world/asia/japan-court-ruling-women-surnames.html|accessdate=19 January 2016|work=The New York Times|date=16 December 2015}}</ref> When marriage is used to adopt a [[Mukoyōshi|male heir]], the husband takes his wife's family name.
[[Transnational marriage|International marriages]] are subject to [[International marriage (Japan)|separate rules]] within Japan. Foreigners in Japan do not have their own family registration sheet, and therefore those who marry a Japanese national are listed on his or her family's sheet.<ref name=USEmbassy/> Foreign spouses in Japan are eligible for a long-term [[Visa policy of Japan|dependent visa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=General visa: Dependent (family stays)|url=http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/long/visa9.html|website=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan|accessdate=19 January 2016|date=22 July 2015}}</ref>
Children born out of wedlock are recorded as [[Legitimacy (family law)|illegitimate]] on their mother's family register, although they can be legitimized by a later acknowledgment of [[Paternity (law)|paternity]]. Illegitimate children were eligible for half the inheritance of legitimate ones until a court ruling in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tamura|first1=Tsuyoshi|title=Top court rules illegitimate children entitled to equal inheritance|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201309040090|accessdate=22 January 2016|work=The Asahi Shimbun|date=4 September 2013}}</ref>
==Wedding ceremonies== [[File:Bride at meiji shrine.jpg|thumb|250px|A bride in ''Tsunokakushi'' and ''shiromuku'' at [[Tokyo]]'s [[Meiji Shrine]].]] A common description of Japan's [[Syncretism|religious syncretism]] says: "Born [[Shinto]], married [[Christianity in Japan|Christian]], die [[Buddhism in Japan|Buddhist]]."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kisala|first1=R|editor1-last=Swanson|editor1-first=P|editor2-last=Chilson|editor2-first=C|title=Nanzan Guide to Japanese Religions|date=2006|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|page=3|edition=3-13|chapter=Japanese Religions}}</ref> In practice, however, elements of all three major traditions tend to be practiced side-by-side. Japanese weddings usually begin with a Shinto or Christian-style ceremony for family members and very close friends before a reception dinner and after-party at a restaurant or hotel banquet hall. There the couple's extended families and friends make speeches and offer {{nihongo|''[[Shūgi-bukuro|goshūgi]]''|ご祝儀||"gift money"}} in a special envelope.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wedding Ceremonies in Japan|url=http://www.hiraganatimes.com/past-articles/society/1017/|accessdate=18 January 2016|work=Hiragana Times|issue=June 2010 Issue|date=9 January 2013}}</ref> Close family pay about twice as much as friends.<ref name="nippon-weddings">{{cite news|title=Weddings in Japan|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/features/jg00016/|accessdate=27 March 2016|work=Nippon.com|date=20 July 2015}}</ref>
===Japanese Shinto ceremonies=== {{main article|Shinto wedding}} Traditional {{Nihongo|Shinto ceremonies|神前式||'shinzen shiki'}}, which account for around one in six of Japanese weddings, are held in the main building of a [[Shinto shrine|shrine]]. A [[kannushi|priest]] performs a ritual purification for the couple, then announces their marriage to the {{Nihongo|''kami''|神||"gods" or "spirits"}} of the shrine and asks for their blessing. The bride and groom take three sips each from three cups of [[sake]], a ritual called {{Nihongo|''sansankudo''|三三九度}}.
Japanese brides, sometimes painted white as a sign of purity before the gods, wear a kimono which is either {{Nihongo|''shiromuku''|白無垢||"pure white dress"}}, {{Nihongo|''iro uchikake''|色打掛||"colorful outer robe"}}, or {{Nihongo|''kurobiki furisode''|黒引き振袖}}, the black and patterned kimono once worn at weddings of the nobility during the Edo period (1603–1868), with either an open white {{Nihongo|''watabōshi''|綿帽子||}} or a {{nihongo|''[[tsunokakushi]]''|角隠し}}. Grooms wear a black crested {{nihongo|''haori''|羽織}} jacket and loose, skirt-like {{nihongo|''hakama''|袴}} with a vertical stripe.<ref name="nippon-weddings"/>
===Christian chapel ceremonies=== [[File:St Mary's Church, Kyoto.jpg|thumb|250px|A [[Christianity in Japan|Christian]] wedding in [[Kyoto]].]] Christian wedding ceremonies have since the mid-1990s displaced the Shinto rite and continue to remain Japan’s wedding ceremony of choice.<ref>LeFebvre, J. (2015). Christian wedding ceremonies: “Nonreligiousness” in contemporary Japan. Japanese Journal of Religious Studies, 42(2), 185-203.</ref> Christian wedding ceremonies have in the last thirty years moved from the sideline to the mainstream of Japanese society. The popularity of Christian wedding ceremonies represents new widespread acceptance, commercialization, and popularity of a religious ceremony. The postwar history of Christian wedding ceremonies is best understood in light of the efforts made by traditional Christian churches and the bridal industry to meet the religious needs and demands of Japan’s largely “nonreligious” (mushūkyō) constituency.<ref name="ReferenceA">LeFebvre, "Christian Wedding Ceremonies-- 'Nonreligiousness" in Contemporary Japan".</ref>
Statistically speaking, the vast majority of contemporary Japanese self-identify as nonreligious. However, this self-identification is far from a wholesale rejection of religion, and often employed both to reject and affirm religious behaviors and identities.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Most typically, nonreligious attitudes reject religious dispositions that are perceived as deviant, unhealthy, or foreign while simultaneously affirming religion’s importance.
Nonreligious individuals tend to rely on religious professionals and vicariously entrust specialized acts of prayer and ritual to religious authorities when desirable and appropriate. Along with various Buddhist and Shinto rites, Christian wedding ceremonies are now one of the occasions where nonreligious Japanese rely on religious professionals. Nonreligious attitudes are responsible for significant transformations in Japanese Christianity and the bridal industry and the successful response of the Christian churches and the bridal industry to consumer demand has led to an explosion in Christian wedding ceremonies.
The story of contemporary Japanese Christianity is one of success and failure in the face of overwhelming “nonreligiousness.” The story of failure depicts the inability of Christian churches to acquire Japanese converts; both transplant and domestic Japanese churches face aging membership and dwindling baptism numbers. In 2006, Christians accounted for 1.2 percent of the Japanese population. Similarly, Christian religious organizations accounted for a mere 2.3 percent of Japan’s 182,468 religious juridical persons. This data, along with an aging church population, led researchers to suggest that a marginal Christian population is headed for rapid decline.
However, these statistics on Christian affiliation do not account for the unprecedented popularity of Christian wedding ceremonies or address how nonreligiousness has altered Japanese Christianity. The growing popularity of Christian weddings dates back to two events in the 1980s. The first was [[Wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer|the wedding]] of [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] to [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]], and the second—among the Japanese—was the televised wedding of the [[Japanese idol]] [[Momoe Yamaguchi]]. By the mid-1990s, Christian weddings surpassed Shinto weddings and, since 1999, continue to be the wedding ceremony of choice among sixty to seventy percent of Tokyo couples with similar trends in popularity throughout the country.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Christian wedding ceremonies have attracted and sustained the interest of a majority of Japanese—the majority of whom are nonreligious. In short, the majority of Japanese are not only “Born Shinto, Die Buddhist,” but they also “Identify nonreligious, Wed Christian.”
Nonreligiousness has transformed the traditional Japanese Christian churches and the bridal industry. Although frequently dismissed as bridal-industry activity, Christian churches and personnel were essential in the rise of Christian weddings and their popularity. On 1 March 1975, the Vatican granted the Japanese Catholic Church special permission to conduct wedding ceremonies for non-affiliated, non-Christian couples. Nonreligious Japanese have access to this Catholic sacrament in a manner on par with baptized church members. These forms of access were instrumental in popularizing the Christian wedding in the late 1980s and the 1990s. The Catholic Church used in Kanda Masaki and Matsuda Seiko’s “wedding ceremony of sacred shining (seiki no kekkon)” became the setting of the 1991 Japanese television series Itsu ka, sarejio kyōkai de and one of the most popular venues in the early years of Christian weddings.
In addition to new policies and approaches, the nonreligious demand for Christian weddings has given rise to new religious institutions and powerful partnerships between commercial and religious groups—occasionally blurring the lines between the two. One successful example of religious and commercial partnership is the Christian Bridal Mission (kirisutokyō buraidaru senkyōdan), which was founded in 1980 and incorporated as a religious juridical person in 1986. From humble beginnings, this non-denominational Evangelical Protestant Church—the first Christian organization devoted exclusively to the production of weddings—grew to national proportions. Currently, the Christian Bridal Mission has over one thousand ministers—making it one of the largest Christian organizations in Japan.
Where the active majority of people are nonreligious, mechanisms for establishing a convincing reference to Christianity takes on a sensual character. Visual cues—minister’s race, architectural style, musical talent, etc.—have become the primary way not only to generate a connection to Christian tradition but to verify that a connection does exist.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The bridal industry relies on sensory experience in almost every conceivable manner with the result that venues of commercial institutions now play a crucial role in the success and continued popularity of Christian weddings as new Protestant churches.
Although the Japanese have unprecedented access to the Catholic Church, the majority of weddings in Japan follow the Protestant liturgy. As such the ceremony includes elements typical to a traditional Protestant wedding including hymns, benedictions, prayers, bible readings, an exchange of rings, wedding kiss, and vows before God. It is typical for a bride to enter with her father and then be "given away" to her husband—an exchange that usually involves bowing and shaking hands. In recent years, the custom of lowering the veil has also become popular. During the veil lowering the mother of the bride lowers the veil for her daughter before she continues down the "virgin road" with her father toward her husband. In the case of a non-Japanese wedding minister, the ceremony is commonly performed in a mix of Japanese and a western language (typically, English).
===Non-religious or civil ceremonies=== Non-religious or civil ceremonies often take place in a banquet hall, before or during the reception party, with a Master of Ceremonies officiating and guests seated around tables. Although these ceremonies often adopt Western elements, especially a [[wedding dress]] for the bride and a [[tuxedo]] for the groom, they forego any religious connotations.<ref name="BBC-priest">{{cite news|title=Faking it as a priest in Japan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6067002.stm|accessdate=29 March 2016|work=BBC|date=2 November 2006}}</ref>
Some younger couples choose to abandon formality entirely for a "no host party" wedding, which emphasizes celebration rather than ceremony. The guests consist primarily of the couple's friends, who pay an attendance fee.<ref>Lebra, T, Sugiyama (1984). Japanese women: constraint and fulfillment. Honolulu University of Hawaii Press, Retrieved 10 January 2009, from NetLibrary</ref>

'''Mortgage burning''' is a twentieth-century [[United States|American]] custom that is the ritual burning of a paid off [[mortgage]] document by homeowners. It is done as a celebratory event, and is sometimes accompanied by a party in which extended family and friends are invited.
==History==
Home mortgage burnings, and particularly home mortgage burning parties, are nearly unheard of in the present-day United States for a few reasons. American families are increasingly mobile, so it is now much less likely that a homeowner will be in a home long enough to make enough monthly payments to fully satisfy a mortgage. Also, starting in the late twentieth century and until the [[Late 2000s Recession|housing bubble]] burst, it was fairly common to get an over-leveraged mortgage, and possibly even an interest-only mortgage, that was intended to eventually be flipped to another mortgage by presumed increasing home value as opposed paying it off via a long series of payments. That, and the refinancing of homes to take advantage of fluctuating interest rates, often leads to refinancing and “resetting the clock” on a mortgage period, lengthening the time that one is subject to a mortgage beyond the period of the original mortgage taken upon purchase of the home.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106242731 |title=Mortgage-Burning Parties Almost Extinct |publisher=NPR |date=2009-07-03 |accessdate=2013-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/695204_Mortgage-burning-parties-still-happen.html |title=Mortgage-Burning Parties Still Happen |publisher=Lancaster Online |date=2012-07-25 |accessdate=2013-04-05}}</ref>
Even when a personal mortgage is paid off at the conclusion of payments, throwing a party to celebrate is now generally considered gauche since the traditional paying off of a mortgage is no longer a standard rite of passage. It is now seen as bragging about one’s secure financial condition. Modern advice columnists and etiquette experts generally advise against having mortgage burning parties attended by anyone other than immediate family.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/10/AR2010091005903.html |title=Miss Manners: Modesty is the best party policy |publisher=Washington Post |date=2010-09-11 |accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref>
Mortgage burning parties are still held by [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] entities such as churches. In those cases, the attendees are generally those who helped to pay the mortgage off.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tri-countybulletin.com/community/orange-county/2903-cor-church-mortgage-burning-party |title=COR Church Mortgage Burning Party |date=2013-01-28 |accessdate=2013-04-07}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenvilleonline.com/article/20130401/NEWS/304010184/Mount-Pisgah-Baptist-holds-mortgage-burning?nclick_check=1 |title=Mount Pisgah Baptist holds mortgage burning |date=2013-04-01 |accessdate=2013-04-07}}</ref>
==In popular culture==
The concept of a mortgage burning party was immortalized in a 1975 episode of ''[[All In The Family]]'', “Mike Makes His Move”.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kzYgrBELU5I |title=All In The Family: Mike Makes His Move |date=1975-03-08 |accessdate=2013-04-05}}</ref> Mortgage burnings were also the premise of a 1977 episode of ''[[Eight Is Enough]]'', "Mortgage Burnin' Blues", and a 1982 episode of ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'', "Settling Debts".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/eight-is-enough-1977/episode-5-season-2/mortgage-burning-blues/201121 |title=Eight Is Enough Episodes on ABC |accessdate=2013-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sharetv.org/shows/mash/episodes/287489 |title=M*A*S*H Episode Guide |accessdate=2013-04-14}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Foreclosure]]

'''People skills''' are patterns of behavior and behavioral interactions. Among people, it is an umbrella term for skills under three related set of abilities: personal effectiveness, interaction skills, and intercession skills.<ref>Neil Thompson (2009). People Skills, Palgrave Macmillan. {{ISBN|0230221122}}</ref> This is an area of exploration about how a person behaves and how they are perceived irrespective of their thinking and feeling.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=fvQkPMIPP9wC Peter Honey (2001). Improve Your People Skills, CIPD Publishing.] {{ISBN|085292903X}}</ref> It is further elaborated as dynamics between personal ecology (cognitive, affective, physical and spiritual dimensions) and its function with other people's [[personality style]]s in numerous environments (life event's, institution's, life challenges...etc.).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=HLdKAgAACAAJ People Skills, Tony Burton]</ref> British dictionary definition is "the ability to communicate effectively with people in a friendly way, especially in business" or personal effectiveness skills.<ref>[http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/british/people-skills "Macmillan Dictionary"] Retrieved on 2009-08-18</ref> In business it is a connection among people in a humane level to achieve productivity.<ref>J Smith. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2013/11/15/the-20-people-skills-you-need-to-succeed-at-work/#7befa7fa64b5 "The 20 People Skills You Need To Succeed At Work"], ''[[Forbes]]'', 15 November 2013. Retrieved on 17 January 2014</ref>
Portland Business Journal describes people skills as:<ref>Rifkin, H. [http://portland.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2002/06/03/focus6.html "Invest in people skills to boost bottom line"] Retrieved on 2009-10-14</ref>
* Ability to effectively communicate, understand, and [[Empathy|empathize]]. * Ability to interact with others [[respect]]fully and develop productive working relationship to minimize conflict and maximize rapport. * Ability to build [[sincerity]] and [[trust (social sciences)|trust]]; moderate behaviors (less [[Impulsivity|impulsive]]) and enhance [[agreeableness]].
== History == Records of guidelines related to "people skills" have been found as early as the New Testament. Five examples of early human guidelines appear in the [[Bible]]. [[First Epistle of Peter|1 Peter]] 4:8-9 advises: "Above all, maintain constant love for one another, for love covers a multitude of sins. Be hospitable to one another without complaining."; and [[Solomon]]'s wisdom in [[Book of Proverbs|Proverbs]] 15:1 includes: "A soft answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.", along similar lines in [[Book of Proverbs|Proverbs]] 16:21 includes: "The wise of heart is called perceptive, and pleasant speech increases persuasiveness."; [[First Epistle to the Thessalonians|1 Thessalonians]] 5:14 dictates: "And we urge you, beloved, to discourage the idlers, encourage the fainthearted, help the weak, be patient with all of them."; [[Epistle to Titus|Titus]] 3:2 advises: " To speak evil of no one, to avoid quarreling, to be gentle, and to show every courtesy to everyone."; and in [[Epistle to the Galatians|Galatians]] 6:2 encourages: "Bear one another's burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the [[Golden Rule|law]] of Christ."<ref>[http://www.biblegateway.com/versions/New-Revised-Standard-Version-NRSV-Bible/ "New Revised Standard Version"] Retrieved on 2009-08-18</ref>
[[human relations|Human-relations]] studies emerged in the 1920s when companies became more interested in "[[soft skills]]" and interpersonal skills of employees.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In organizations, improving people skills became a specialized role of the [[corporate trainer]]. By the mid-1930s, [[Dale Carnegie]] popularized people skills in ''[[How to Win Friends and Influence People]]'' and ''[[How to Stop Worrying and Start Living]]'' worldwide.
In the 1960s, US schools introduced people-skills topics and methods—often as a way to promote better [[self-esteem]], communication and social interaction. These encompassed psychologist [[Thomas Gordon (psychologist)|Thomas Gordon]]'s "Effectiveness Training" variations as well as many other training programs.<ref>Schaps, E.; Cohen, A.Y.; and Resnik, H.S.: [http://www.pire.org/detail.asp?detayl=y&core=11989 "Balancing Head and Heart"] PIRE. Retrieved on 2009-08-18 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727175001/http://www.pire.org/detail.asp?detayl=y&core=11989 |date=2011-07-27 }}</ref> (By the 1980s, "[[traditional education]]" and a "back-to-basics" [[The three Rs|three-Rs]] emphasis largely pushed these programs aside,<ref>Doll, R.C. [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/32/83/49.pdf "Humanizing Education by Improving Communication"] ERIC. Retrieved on 2009-08-19{{Dead link|date=September 2016}}</ref> with notable exceptions.<ref>[http://learningmatters.tv/blog/on-the-newshour/stop-think-act-the-program/2301/ "Stop. Think. Act. Program"] Learning Matters. Retrieved on 2009-08-18 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802203420/http://learningmatters.tv/blog/on-the-newshour/stop-think-act-the-program/2301/ |date=2009-08-02 }}</ref>)
The first documented use of the phrase "people skills" was around 1970.<ref>[https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=People+skills&case_insensitive=on&year_start=1900&year_end=2008&corpus=15&smoothing=3&share=&direct_url=t4%3B%2CPeople%20skills%3B%2Cc0%3B%2Cs0%3B%3Bpeople%20skills%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BPeople%20Skills%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BPeople%20skills%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BPEOPLE%20SKILLS%3B%2Cc0 Ngram for people skills]</ref>
== Business impact == The SCANS report states that business, labor and government authorities agree that having a wide range of people skills are necessary for 20th-century work success.<ref>[http://wdr.doleta.gov/SCANS/ "Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills (SCANS)"] US Dept. of Labor. Retrieved on 2009-08-18</ref> Skills like customer service, building effective relationships, and teamwork are among the abilities most requested by employers in job postings.<ref>[http://burning-glass.com/research/baseline-skills/ "The Human Factor: The Hard Time Employers Have Finding Soft Skills,"] Burning Glass Technologies, November 2015</ref> Lack of these skills is considered a serious psychological handicap. Constructive leadership based companies engage in helping individuals to grow, and through that growth employees take more responsibility and discharge it effectively. This in-turn will enhance the basic attitude of the individual; and that will reflect the general level of performance in workplace. Studies indicate that many people who have difficulty in obtaining or holding a job possess the needed technical competence but lack interpersonal competence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/social-sciences-and-law/economics-business-and-labor/businesses-and-occupations/human-relations|title=Human Relations facts, information, pictures {{!}} Encyclopedia.com articles about Human Relations|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-06}}</ref>
[[Lawrence A. Appley]] of American Management Association, reflected on these trainings as a responsibility to "increase the knowledge, sharpen and add to the skills, improve the habits, and change the attitudes of many of those for whose development we are responsible."<ref>Harwood F Merrill & Elizabeth Marting (1952). Developing Executive Skills, American Management Association, NY.</ref> Lack of people skills among upper echelons<ref>http://www.palgraveconnect.com/esm/doifinder/10.1057/9781137294678.0713</ref> (top management) can result in [[bullying]] and/or [[harassment]], which is not uncommon in the modern workplace due to changing values. The causes that are most identified with the situation are lack of necessary motivation, communication, influencing skills and [[empathy gap]] among upper echelons (Gilbert and Thompson, 2002). Training company staff in people skills and interpersonal skills increases the morale and dignity at work (Best, 2010). Employers that do not take steps to prevent harassment can face major costs in decreased productivity, low morale, increased absenteeism and health care costs, and potential legal expenses.
== Educational Importance == The Collaborative for Academic Social and Emotional Learning (CASEL) has identified 22 programs in the US that are especially comprehensive in social-emotional learning coverage and effective in documented impacts.<ref>[http://www.casel.org/programs/selecting.php "CASEL "Select" Programs"] Retrieved on 2009-08-18 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501183345/http://www.casel.org/programs/selecting.php |date=2009-05-01 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2004/01/mind.aspx "Century of research confirms impact of psychosocial factors on health"] APA. Retrieved on 2015-10-18</ref> UNESCO research found that young people who develop speaking/listening skills and who get to know others without WIIFM<ref>http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/WIIFM</ref> attitude have improved [[self-awareness]], social-emotional adjustment and classroom behavior; in addition, self-destructive and violent behavior also decreased.<ref>[http://www.btbetterworld.com/the_better_world_campaign/reasons_for_our_campaign "UNESCO Research"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104013540/http://www.btbetterworld.com/the_better_world_campaign/reasons_for_our_campaign |date=2007-11-04 }} British Telecommunications. Retrieved on 2009-08-18</ref> People skills are also important for teachers in effective classroom management. Educators have found that more is needed than a degree in the field they are teaching. Knowing how to communicate and teach people instead of simply teaching their subject will help make a difference in the classroom.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=MJPAoB22ugkC&oi=fnd&pg=PR13&dq=people+skills&ots=zV_H_zoADq&sig=bk9P20WbF6_xYoib8STfUo6_SOw#v=onepage&q=people%20skills&f=false|title=People Skills|last=Bolton|first=Robert|date=2009-11-24|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439188347|language=en}}</ref> It is identified that 50 percent of classroom success lies in effective interpersonal relationships while the other 50 percent lies within academic skills.<ref>Jerry Boyle, (2011). It's All about People Skills: Surviving Challenges in the Classroom. {{ISBN|1610486102}}</ref> Requirement of people skills education is greatly emphasized within higher education and recruiters stress the required focus on this skills for securing entry level jobs right off from campus placements.<ref>Fellers, J. W. (1996). People Skills: Using the Cooperative Learning Model to Teach Students "People Skills". ''Interfaces'', ''26''(5), 42-49.</ref>
== See also == {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Big Five personality traits]] * [[Communication skills training]] * [[Emotional and/or behavioral disability]] * [[Emotional intelligence]] * [[Emotional literacy]] * [[Life skills]] * [[Social intelligence]] * [[Social skills]] * [[Soft skills]] }}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book|author=Robert Bolton|title=People Skills: How to Assert Yourself, Listen to Others, and Resolve Conflicts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sAAuBAAAQBAJ|year=1979|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-7318-1128-1}} * [https://elguide.cc People Skills & Self-Management (online guide)], Alliances for Psychosocial Advancements in Living (APAL) * The People Skills Revolution: A Step-by-Step Approach to Developing Sophisticated People Skills [https://web.archive.org/web/20120314035011/http://www.gppbooks.com/book.php?id=818615] Pamela Milne, Global Professional Publishing

{{Taxobox | image = Hysteroconcha dione.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Mollusca]] | classis = [[Bivalvia]] | ordo = [[Veneroida]] | familia = [[Veneridae]] | genus = ''[[Pitar]]'' | species = '''''P. dione''''' | binomial = ''Pitar dione'' | binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], 1758) | synonyms = * ''Venus dione'' * ''Hysteroconcha dione''<ref>[http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=507709 World Register of Marine Species]</ref> }}
'''''Pitar (Hysteroconcha) dione''''', or the '''elegant Venus clam''', formerly known as '''''Venus dione''''', is a species of [[bivalve]] [[mollusc]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Veneridae]], the Venus clams. The shell is whitish pink, with a row of long curved spines on each valve.
The species was named in ''[[Systema Naturae]]'' in 1758 by the Swedish naturalist [[Linnaeus]]. Both there and in his 1771 ''Fundamenta Testaceologiae'', he described the shell in "disquieting[ly]"<ref name=Grout/> sexual terms.
==Etymology== The species was named in 1758 by the Swedish naturalist [[Linnaeus]] as ''Venus dione'', [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] being the name of the Roman goddess of love, and especially of sex.<ref name=Grout>{{cite web| url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/~grout/encyclopaedia_romana/aconite/dacosta.html | title=Da Costa and the Venus dione: The Obscenity of Shell Description | accessdate=19 May 2015}} From the ''Encyclopædia Romana'' by James Grout.</ref>
The specific epithet ''dione'' is the name of [[Dione (mythology)|the mother of Venus]] in Roman mythology.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bronze statuette of Venus or her mother, Dione |url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/gr/b/bronze_of_venus_or_dione.aspx |publisher=British Museum |accessdate=19 May 2015}}</ref> The later generic name ''Hysteroconcha'' is from Greek ''hyster'', [[womb]], and Latin ''concha'', shell.
==In human culture: the Venus shell== [[File:Venus dione Linnaeus.jpg|thumb|left|200 px|Linnaeus's drawing of ''Venus dione'' in his ''Fundamenta Testaceologiae'', 1771, labelled with overtly sexual descriptors]] In his 1758 ''[[Systema Naturae]]'', and then in his 1771 ''Fundamenta Testaceologiae'', Linnaeus used a series of "disquieting[ly]"<ref name=Grout/> sexual terms to describe the shell: ''[[vulva]]'', ''[[anus]]'', ''nates'' ([[buttocks]]), ''[[pubis (bone)|pubis]]'', ''[[mons veneris]]'', ''[[labia]]'', ''[[hymen]]''.<ref name=Grout/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Linnaeus |title=Systema Naturae |date=1758 |pages=684–685 |edition=10th}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Linnaeus |title=Systema Naturae |date=1767 |pages=1128–1129 |edition=12th}}</ref> The evolutionary biologist [[Stephen Jay Gould]] called Linnaeus's description "one of the most remarkable paragraphs in the history of systematics".<ref name=Grout/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gould |first1=Stephen Jay |title=The Anatomy Lesson: The Teachings of Naturalist Mendes da Costa, a Sephardic Jew in King George's Court |journal=Natural History |date=1995 |volume=104 |issue=12 |pages=10–15, 62–63}}</ref> Some later naturalists found the terms used by Linnaeus uncomfortable; an 1803 review commented that "a few of these terms however strongly they may be warranted by the similitudes and analogies which they express, ... are not altogether reconcilable with the delicacy proper to be observed in ordinary discourse",<ref name=Grout/> while the 1824 ''Supplement to the Encyclopædia Britannica'' criticised Linnaeus for "indulg[ing] in obscene allusions."<ref name=Grout/>
[[File: Veneridae - Hysteroconcha dione.JPG|thumb|240px|right|A valve of ''Pitar dione'']]
==Description== The shells of ''Pitar dione'' can reach a length of about {{convert|72|mm}}.<ref name=BB/><ref name=AA/> The color of the whole shell is very pale or whitish pink, with whitish interior. The anterior end is broadly rounded, while the posterior is lightly sloping.<ref name=AA/> The surface of each valve is characterized by several sharpened concentric and prominent ribs.<ref>Baron Georges Cuvier, Edward Griffith, and Edward Pidgeon - The Mollusca and Radiata (1834) - The Naturalist's Miscellany: or Coloured Figures of Natural Objects</ref> This rare species is unusual in that it has a double series of long, curved spines on the posterior slope of each valve. A closely related species from the Eastern Pacific is ''[[Pitar lupanaria]]''.
==Distribution== This species is found in the [[Gulf of Mexico]], from eastern [[Mexico]] to the [[West Indies]].<ref>Abbott, R.T. & Morris, P.A. ''A Field Guide to Shells: Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and the West Indies.'' New York: Houghton Mifflin, 1995. 68-69.</ref>
==Habitat== This species lives in intertidal zones and moderately shallow waters.<ref name=BB>[http://eol.org/pages/4768489/overview Encyclopedia of life]</ref><ref name=AA>R. Tucker Abbott, Percy A. Morris [https://books.google.it/books?id=Jpk_EKysBxwC&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=Pitar+dione+length&source=bl&ots=eF5acaXl7m&sig=U56I1iWcg81qCNT7GI_NCQg1OWY&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiA1LHcio7NAhVFsBQKHSiEANUQ6AEIIzAA#v=onepage&q=Pitar%20dione%20length&f=false A Field Guide to Shells: Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and the West Indies]</ref>
==Bibliography== * Baron [[Georges Cuvier]], Edward Griffith, and Edward Pidgeon - The Mollusca and Radiata (1834) - The Naturalist's Miscellany: or Coloured Figures of Natural Objects; * [[Carl von Linné]] - ''Fundamenta Testaceologiæ'' (1771) * Eleanor Winsor Leach - "Plautus' Rudens: Venus Born from a Shell" (1974) - Texas Studies in Literature and Language (Special Classics Issue), 15, 915-931. * [[Emanuel Mendes da Costa]] - Elements of Conchology: or, An Introduction to the Knowledge of Shells (1776) * G. S. Rousseau and David Haycock - "The Jew of Crane Court: Emanuel Mendes da Costa (1717-91), Natural History and Natural Excess" (2000) - Historical Society, 38, 127-170; * [[Geoffrey Cantor]] - "The Rise and Fall of Emanuel Mendes da Costa: A Severe Case of 'The Philosophical Dropsy'?" (2001) The English Historical Review, 116(467), 584-603; * George Shaw, F. P. Nodder - Drawn and Described Immediately from Nature (1789-1813) * P. J. P. Whitehead - "Emanuel Mendes da Costa (1717-91) and the 'Conchology, or Natural History of Shells'" (1977) - Bulletin of the British Museum (Historical Series), 6(1), 1-24; * P. Martin-Kaye - "Sorting of Lamellibranch Valves on Beaches in Trinidad, B.W.I" (1951) - Geological Magazine, 88(66), 432-434; * R. M. Carter - "On the Nature and Definition of the Lunule, Escutcheon and Corcelet in the Bivalvia" (1967) - Journal of Molluscan Studies, 37, 243-263; * [[Stephen Jay Gould]] - "The Anatomy Lesson: The Teachings of Naturalist Mendes da Costa, a Sephardic Jew in King George's Court" (1995) - Natural History, 104(12), 10-15, 62-63; * Veronica Carpita, Rainer Willmann, and Sophia Willmann - Antoine-Joseph Dezallier d'Argenville: Shells (2009) * William George Maton and Rev. Thomas Rackett - "An Historical Account of Testaceological Writers" (1804) - Transactions of the Linnean Society of London, 7(1), 119-244;
